abstractContent.text: We present a simple method for ever-growing extraction of predicate paraphrases from news headlines in Twitter.

We also demonstrate that our resource is to a large extent complementary to existing resources, providing many novel paraphrases.
Our resource is publicly available, continuously expanding based on daily news.

introductionContent.text: Recognizing that various textual descriptions across multiple texts refer to the same event or action can benefit NLP applications such as recognizing textual entailment ( and question answering.

For example, to answer "when did the US Supreme Court approve samesex marriage?" given the text "In June 2015, the Supreme Court ruled for same-sex marriage", approve and ruled for should be identified as describing the same action.
To that end, much effort has been devoted to identifying predicate paraphrases, some of which resulted in releasing resources of predicate entailment or paraphrases.
Two main approaches were proposed for that matter; the first leverages the similarity in argument distribution across a large corpus between two predicates (e.g.).
The second approach exploits bilingual parallel corpora, extracting as paraphrases pairs of texts that were translated identically to foreign languages (.
While these methods have produced exhaustive resources which are broadly used by applications, their accuracy is limited.

Specifically, the first approach may extract antonyms, that also have similar argument distribution (e.g. 0 raise to 1 / [a] 0 fall to 1 ) while the second may conflate multiple senses of the foreign phrase.
A third approach was proposed to harvest paraphrases from multiple mentions of the same event in news articles.

introductionContent.text: We apply our methodology to create a resource of predicate paraphrases, exemplified in.
Analysis of the resource obtained after ten weeks of acquisition shows that the set of paraphrases reaches accuracy of 60-86% at different levels of support.

Comparison to existing resources shows that, even as our resource is still smaller in orders of magnitude from existing resources, it complements them with nonconsecutive predicates (e.g. take 0 from [a] 1 ) and paraphrases which are highly context specific.
The resource and the source code are available at http://github.com/vered1986/ Chirps.
As of the end of May 2017, it contains 456,221 predicate pairs in 1,239,463 different contexts.
Our resource is ever-growing and is expected to contain around 2 million predicate paraphrases within a year.
Until it reaches a large enough size, we will release a daily update, and at a later stage, we plan to release a periodic update.
